quoteFirst: She went back to her room, leaving the door ajar so that she could hear when Chris came in. He was very late--she heard the clock strike twelve, and then half-past, but still he did not come; and then--at
quoteLast: she heard a taxi drive up to the door and voices on the path outside.
title: A Bachelor Husband
author: Ayres, Ruby M. (Ruby Mildred), 1883-1955; Stahr, Paul, 1883-1953 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Remember yesterday, Peter?--when you were coming back at ten o'clock and came at four? No more unlimited contracts from me. It is
quoteLast: now. You can get in by two thirty if you hustle. I must start in by half-past four. It wouldn't be safe to wait any longer."
title: Captivating Mary Carstairs
author: Harrison, Henry Sydnor, 1880-1930

quoteLast: --If there is in the world at this moment a thoroughly astonished man it is JOHN WILLIAM LOGAN, Member of Parliament for the South (Harborough) division of Leicestershire. Just now LOGAN'S mind is disturbed and his collar ruffled by an incident in the passage of Home-Rule Bill; but he is capable of giving perfectly coherent account of events.
title: Punch, or the London Charivari, Vol. 105,  August  5th 1893
author: Various; Burnand, F. C. (Francis Cowley), 1836-1917 [Editor]

quoteFirst: So, with one of Dr. Mason's cameras under the seat, we started back through the sweet-smelling lanes; and, at about
quoteLast: , swung past the gate lodge and up the long avenue, the wheels grinding crisply upon the newly wetted gravel. There was but little moon, now, and the house stood up, an irregular black mass, before us.
title: The Haunting of Low Fennel
author: Rohmer, Sax, 1883-1959

quoteFirst: “At a quarter-past one, or a few minutes later,” she said, “that bouquet was lying in the middle of the road. Let us say
quoteLast: , because I came straight home, took off my hat, and was ready for lunch. It was more like a haystack than a bouquet: I’m sure if I hadn’t stepped over it, I should have tripped and fallen.
title: Mrs. Ames
author: Benson, E. F. (Edward Frederic), 1867-1940

quoteFirst: “The firing began at thirty-six minutes past twelve, and continued till
quoteLast: . I am happy to say we had a very small loss. I feel much indebted to Captain Ayscough of the Success, for the assistance received from him, and particularly to Captain Milford of the Espoir.
title: Memoir of the Life and Services of Vice-Admiral Sir Jahleel Brenton, Baronet, K.C.B.
author: Raikes, Henry, 1782-1854 [Editor]

quoteFirst: A stranger arrived at Forkville at
quoteLast: , Tuesday, February the tenth. He carried a light pack on his shoulders, and his snowshoes atop the pack. The road was good.
title: Green Timber Thoroughbreds
author: Roberts, Theodore Goodridge, 1877-1953

quoteFirst: Claughton rose and went to the door to look out at the clock, but was seized with faintness, returned and rang the electric bell. Mr. Buckley found her on the ground. She was able to ask the time, which was about
quoteLast: Then fainted, and the Buckleys undressed her and put her to bed.
title: True Ghost Stories
author: Carrington, Hereward, 1880-1959

quoteFirst: "We did not wish to hinder the other churches, and that spirit went into all our plans. First, then, we decided that our services should begin at twelve o'clock every Sunday, and close at one or before
quoteLast: . That gave our parishioners a chance to go to the other churches if they wanted to. I traveled from Boston to St. Louis, and returned _via_ Washington, to engage talent for our pulpit.
title: 'Charge It': Keeping Up With Harry
author: Bacheller, Irving, 1859-1950

quoteFirst: Do not fear any of us, we are all devoted to this cause, and to-day shall see the end. The time is coming for action; to-day this Vampire is limit to the powers of man, and till sunset he may not change. It will take him time to arrive here--see, it is
quoteLast: --and there are yet some times before he can hither come, be he never so quick. What we must hope for is that my Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.
title: Dracula
author: Stoker, Bram, 1847-1912

quoteFirst: Claughton rose, lit the candle, and opened the door. There was no one there. She noticed the clock outside pointed to
quoteLast: She shut the door, got into bed, read, and, leaving the candle burning, went to sleep. Woke up, finding the candle spluttering out. Heard a sound like a sigh.
title: True Ghost Stories
author: Carrington, Hereward, 1880-1959

quoteLast: on the morning of the 10th of July a boy went into a coffee-shop next door to Mrs. Squires’ house, and said he had seen blood on the counter of the unfortunate woman’s shop.
title: Charles Peace, or The Adventures of a Notorious Burglar

quoteLast: 1.--Up boat, filled, and made all sail as before. Observed the _Pallas_ bear up and follow us with her convoy.
title:

quoteFirst: At the distance of a league we passed a fine cattle hacienda, and at
quoteLast: reached Timucui, a small village five leagues from Merida. This village consisted of a few Indian huts, built around a large open square, and on one side was a sort of shed for a casa real.
title: Incidents of Travel in Yucatan, Vol. I.
author: Stephens, John L., 1805-1852

quoteLast: all companies were reported to be in their places. No. 1 under Lieut. Pixley and No. 4 under Captain Paton, with two mopping-up platoons from No.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3

quoteFirst: And he repeated a score of times that she had taken the train at ten minutes past eleven and must have reached Batignolles about half-past twelve. As she had handed in the telegram at
quoteLast: it seemed more likely that she had found the lad already dead.

author: Zola, Émile, 1840-1902; Vizetelly, Ernest Alfred, 1853-1922 [Translator]
